14.1: Thus, the fourteenth chapter: The Yoga of the Division of the Three Gunas. n'The Supreme Lord said: n'I shall explain to you once more the supreme knowledge of knowledge. n'By knowing which, all the sages attained the supreme perfection.'
14.2: Those who have attained my nature by relying on this knowledge, n'do not get reborn even in creation, nor do they suffer in dissolution.
14.3-4: My source is the great Brahman, and I place the seed into it. n'From that, all beings are born, O Bharata. n'Among all the wombs, O Kounteya, the wombs of the Divine are the great womb. n'I am the father who gives the seed.
14.5: The three gunas—sattva, rajas, and tamas—originate from nature. n'They bind the imperishable soul in the body, O mighty-armed one.
14.6: Among them, sattva is pure, and it binds by giving light and knowledge. n'It binds by the attachment to happiness and knowledge, O sinless one.
14.7: Know rajas to be born of desire and attachment. n'It binds by attachment to action and desire, O Kounteya.
14.8: Know tamas to be born of ignorance. n'It binds all beings with delusion, laziness, and sleep, O Bharata.
14.9: Sattva binds by creating happiness, while rajas binds by action, O Bharata. n'Tamas binds by obscuring knowledge and causing negligence.
14.10: When rajas and tamas dominate, sattva emerges. n'When rajas dominates, sattva and tamas also emerge; when tamas dominates, sattva and rajas also emerge.
14.11-13: When sattva predominates, light and knowledge arise in all the senses of the body. n'When rajas predominates, greed, activity, and desire arise. n'When tamas predominates, darkness, inactivity, and delusion arise.
14.14-15: When sattva prevails, the soul goes to the highest realm of the pure. n'When rajas prevails, it goes to the realms of the active. n'When tamas prevails, it goes to the realms of ignorance and delusion.
14.16: The result of sattvic action is pure and righteous. n'The result of rajasic action is sorrow and ignorance. n'The result of tamasic action is delusion and ignorance.
14.17: From sattva arises knowledge, from rajas arises greed. n'From tamas arise delusion and ignorance.
14.18: Those who are established in sattva ascend, while those in rajas remain in the middle. n'Those in tamas descend.
14.19: When one sees that the self is beyond the gunas and perceives the gunas as separate from the self, n'one attains my state.
14.20: One who transcends these three gunas, which arise from the body, n'becomes free from birth, death, old age, and suffering, and attains immortality.
14.21: Arjuna said: n'By what signs does one who has transcended these three gunas become recognized, O Lord? n'And what is the conduct of one who has transcended these gunas?
14.22-23: The Supreme Lord said: n'He who neither hates the manifestations of the gunas nor longs for their cessation, n'and who remains indifferent and unaffected by them, is said to have transcended the gunas.
14.24-25: One who is even-minded in pleasure and pain, n'who is the same towards a lump of earth, a stone, and gold, n'who is equally affectionate and indifferent, and who is steadfast in praise and blame, is said to have transcended the gunas.
14.26: He who serves me with unwavering devotion and devotion n'passes beyond these gunas and attains the divine nature.
14.27: I am the foundation of Brahman, of immortality, and of imperishability. n'Of the eternal Dharma, and of ultimate happiness. Thus ends the fourteenth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita, named 'The Yoga of the Division of the Three Gunas,' in the Upanishads, in the knowledge of Brahman, and in the dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna.

15.1: Thus ends the Fifteenth Chapter. The Yoga of the Supreme Person. The Blessed Lord said: They speak of the Ashvattha tree as having its roots above and branches below, and its leaves as the Vedic hymns. He who knows this tree is the knower of the Vedas. (1)
15.2: Its branches spread below and above, nourished by the Gunas. The branches are the objects of the senses, and the roots, which are spread out below, are the actions binding humans to the world. (2)
15.3-4: Its form is not here perceptible, nor its end, nor its beginning, nor its foundation. Cutting asunder this firm-rooted Ashvattha tree with the axe of detachment, (3) Then one should seek that place from which having gone, they never return. That is the Supreme Person, the ancient being, from whom the flow of creation has proceeded. (4)
15.5: Free from pride and delusion, having conquered the evil of attachment, ever remaining in the Self, and freed from the dualities of pleasure and pain, such a person reaches the eternal state. (5)
15.6: It is not illumined by the sun, nor by the moon, nor by fire. Having reached which, they do not return; that is My supreme abode. (6)
15.7: The living entity in this world is My eternal fragment. It is called the Jiva, and it is subjected to the six senses, which are engaged in the activities of nature. (7)
15.8: The body that it acquires and the body that it leaves, the soul, taking them up, moves on, like the wind taking up scents. (8)
15.9: The hearing, sight, touch, taste, and smell, which are controlled by the mind, are all used to experience the objects of the senses. (9)
15.10: When the soul leaves the body or remains in it, or enjoys the qualities of life, the deluded do not perceive it; only those with the eye of wisdom perceive it. (10)
15.11: The yogis who strive see it, the Self, established within; but the ignorant, having not purified their minds, do not see it. (11)
15.12: The light which illumines the world is the sun; and what is in the moon and in fire, that light know to be Mine. (12)
15.13: I enter into the Earth and support all beings by My power. I nourish all plants as the Soma, becoming the essence of their sap. (13)
15.14: Becoming the digestive fire in the bodies of living beings, I join with the vital breaths and digest the four kinds of food. (14)
15.15: I am seated in the hearts of all beings. From Me come memory, knowledge, and forgetfulness. I alone am to be known by all the Vedas. I am the compiler of the Vedas and the knower of the Vedas. (15)
15.16: There are two types of beings in the world: the perishable and the imperishable. All beings are perishable, while the imperishable is said to be the eternal essence. (16)
15.17: There is another Supreme Person, called the Supreme Soul, who, pervading all three worlds, upholds the imperishable. (17)
15.18: Because I am beyond the perishable and even superior to the imperishable, I am celebrated as the Supreme Person in this world and in the Vedas. (18)
15.19: He who, not deluded, knows Me as the Supreme Person, worships Me with all his being. (19)
15.20:
Thus, I have explained this most confidential science. By knowing this, one becomes wise and fulfills all duties. (20) 

Thus ends the Fifteenth Chapter of the Bhagavad Gita in the Upanishads, which is the Yoga of the Supreme Person in the dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna.

16.1-3:
Chapter 16: The Division between the Divine and the Demoniacal

The Blessed Lord said:
1. Fearlessness, purity of heart, steadiness in knowledge and yoga, charity, self-control, and performance of sacrifice, study, and straightforwardness.
2. Non-violence, truthfulness, freedom from anger, renunciation, peace, and freedom from malice.
3. Compassion towards all living beings, absence of envy, gentleness, modesty, and absence of fickleness.

These constitute the divine qualities of one born with divine nature, O Bharata.
16.4: 4. Hypocrisy, arrogance, ego, anger, harshness, and ignorance are the qualities of one with demoniacal nature.
16.5: 5. The divine qualities lead to liberation, while the demoniacal ones bind the soul. Do not grieve, O Pandava, for you have divine qualities.
16.6: 6. There are two types of beings in this world: the divine and the demoniacal. I will describe them to you in detail, O Partha.
16.7: 7. Those of demoniacal nature do not know about the concepts of activity and inactivity. They do not possess cleanliness, proper conduct, or truthfulness.
16.8: 8. They declare that the universe is unreal, without a god, and born from mutual union, driven by desire.
16.9: 9. Adhering to such a view, those with lost souls and little understanding perform intense and destructive actions, leading to the world's ruin.
16.10: 10. Driven by insatiable desire and accompanied by hypocrisy, pride, and delusion, they engage in impure rituals.
16.11: 11. They are overwhelmed by an infinite anxiety and regard enjoyment as the ultimate goal, firmly believing that this is the purpose of life.
16.12: 12. Bound by a hundred ties of hope and driven by desire and anger, they pursue unfair means to accumulate wealth for their sensual pleasures.
16.13-15:
13. 'Today I have gained this, and I will fulfill my desires. I have more wealth, and I will acquire more in the future.'
14. 'I have killed such and such a foe and will kill others as well. I am the supreme lord, enjoying pleasures, powerful, and content.'
15. 'I am wealthy and of noble birth; who else is equal to me? I will give charity and rejoice,'—thus deluded by ignorance.
16.16: 16. Those who are confused and entangled in the web of delusion, attached to sensual pleasures, fall into impure states and hell.
16.17: 17. Being self-conceited, stubborn, and filled with pride and arrogance, they worship deities with ritualistic ceremonies performed out of pretense.
16.18: 18. They are afflicted by ego, power, arrogance, desire, and anger, and they harbor enmity and envy towards others.
16.19-20:
19. I constantly cast such cruel and envious beings into the demoniacal wombs, in this world and the next.
20. Being born in demoniacal wombs repeatedly, they attain a wretched end, not attaining Me.
16.21: 21. There are three doors leading to hell: desire, anger, and greed. One should renounce these three.
16.22: 22. One who is freed from these three doors of darkness, O Kounteya, practices righteousness and reaches the highest goal.
16.23: 23. One who disregards the scriptural injunctions and acts according to his own desires, attains neither success, happiness, nor the supreme goal.
16.24:
24. Therefore, you should understand the scriptural instructions as the standard for determining what is to be done and what is not to be done. Knowing this, you should perform your duty accordingly.

Thus ends the sixteenth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita, entitled 'The Division between the Divine and the Demoniacal'.

17.1:
Chapter 17: The Yoga of the Threefold Faith
Arjuna said: Those who, discarding scriptural ordinances, worship with faith, what is their state, O Krishna? Is it Sattva, Rajas, or Tamas? 
1
17.2:
The Blessed Lord said: Threefold is the faith of the embodied beings, inherent in their own nature: Sattvic, Rajasic, and Tamasic. Hear about these. 
2
17.3:
According to the modes of nature, the faith of all beings is in accordance with their nature. The man is indeed what his faith is. 
3
17.4:
The Sattvic worshippers adore the gods, the Rajasic worshippers the spirits and Yakshas, while the Tamasic worshippers worship spirits of the dead and ghosts. 
4
17.5-6:
Those who perform severe penance not prescribed by the scriptures, accompanied by hypocrisy and pride, and who are driven by desire and attachment, torture their bodies and Me, who resides within them. Know them to be of Asuric nature. 
5
6
17.7:
The food which is dear to each is also of three kinds. Hear about this division in Yajna, penance, and charity. 
7
17.8:
The Sattvic food increases life, knowledge, strength, health, joy, and satisfaction. It is oily, smooth, substantial, and agreeable. 
8
17.9:
The Rajasic food, which is hot, spicy, bitter, dry, and burning, causes pain, grief, and disease. 
9
17.10:
The Tamasic food, which is tasteless, putrid, decomposed, and impure, and which is left over and untouchable, is disliked. 
10
17.11:
The Yajna performed by those who desire no reward, according to the rules, is Sattvic. 
11
17.12:
The Yajna performed with the desire for reward, with hypocrisy, and aiming at fame, is Rajasic. 
12
17.13:
The Yajna performed without any regard to the scriptures, without mantras, without offerings, and with no faith, is Tamasic. 
13
17.14:
Worship of the gods, Brahmins, teachers, and wise men, cleanliness, simplicity, celibacy, and non-violence, these constitute bodily penance. 
14
17.15:
The penance of speech is that which is spoken truthfully, pleasing, and beneficial, and also the study of the scriptures. 
15
17.16:
The penance of the mind consists of tranquility, gentleness, silence, self-control, and purity of thought. 
16
17.17:
The penance performed with supreme faith, without desiring a result, is called Sattvic. 
17
17.18:
The penance done for honor and respect, with ostentation, is called Rajasic. It is unstable and transient. 
18
17.19:
The penance performed with delusion, causing self-torture or torturing others, and for the purpose of harming others, is Tamasic. 
19
17.20:
The charity given to one who does not expect any return, at the right place and time, and to a worthy person, is Sattvic. 
20
17.21:
The charity given with the expectation of something in return, or given with difficulty, and to an unworthy person, is Rajasic. 
21
17.22:
The charity given at an inappropriate time and place, and to an undeserving person, is Tamasic. 
22
17.23:
The word Om Tat Sat is declared to be the threefold designation of Brahman. It was used in the Vedas, in sacrifices, and in ancient scriptures. 
23
17.24:
Therefore, the actions of sacrifice, charity, and penance are always performed according to the instructions of the scriptures, with the utterance of Om. 
24
17.25:
Without desiring a reward, the actions of sacrifice, charity, and penance are performed by those who seek liberation. 
25
17.26-27:
The term 'Sat' is used in relation to what is auspicious and virtuous. It is used for praise-worthy actions. In sacrifice, penance, and charity, the condition of 'Sat' is to be understood. 
26
27
17.28:
Whatever is done without faith, whether it is a sacrifice, charity, or penance, is called Asat, O Partha. It does not lead to any benefit here or hereafter. 
28
This is the seventeenth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita, called The Yoga of the Threefold Faith.

18.1:
Chapter 18: The Yoga of Liberation by Renunciation
Arjuna said: O Krishna, I wish to understand the true nature of renunciation (sannyasa) and of renunciation of action (tyaga), and the distinction between the two.
18.2: The Blessed Lord said: The sages declare that there are two types of renunciation: the renunciation of actions with desires and the renunciation of actions without desires. The learned call the former 'renunciation' and the latter 'renunciation'.
18.3: Some sages say that all actions should be abandoned, while others say that sacrifices, charity, and penance should not be abandoned.
18.4: Hear from Me the true nature of renunciation, O best of the Bharatas. Renunciation is declared to be of three kinds.
18.5: Acts of sacrifice, charity, and penance should not be abandoned but should be performed. Sacrifice, charity, and penance are purifiers of the soul.
18.6: But even these actions should be performed without attachment and desire for the results. This is My conclusive opinion.
18.7: Renunciation of obligatory duties is not appropriate for a person who is in the mode of goodness. Such renunciation is regarded as tamasic (in the mode of ignorance).
18.8: One who renounces actions due to fear of physical discomfort, considering it to be painful, performs a rajasic (passionate) renunciation and does not achieve the result of renunciation.
18.9: One who performs actions that are obligatory, with detachment and without desire for results, is considered to perform a sattvic (pure) renunciation.
18.10: The renouncer who is free from attachment and does not desire the results of actions is said to be endowed with sattva (goodness), and is a wise person.
18.11: No one can completely renounce action. The one who renounces the results of actions is considered a true renouncer.
18.12: The results of actions are of three kinds—unpleasant, pleasant, and mixed. These three types of results come to the renouncer after death, but not to the true renouncer.
18.13: Understand from Me the five causes for the accomplishment of all actions, which have been enumerated in the Sankhya philosophy for the accomplishment of all actions.
18.14: The five causes are: the body, the doer, the different senses, the different efforts, and divine providence.
18.15-16: Whatever action is performed by the body, speech, or mind, whether it is right or wrong, is to be attributed to these five causes. Thus, the doer who acts without understanding, considers himself to be the sole actor and is deluded.
18.17: One who is not attached to the results of actions and is free from the egoistic sense of doership is not bound by the actions he performs.
18.18: Knowledge, the object of knowledge, and the knower are all three types of knowledge.
18.19: Knowledge, action, and the doer are all differentiated according to the three gunas (modes of nature). Hear from Me about these differences.
18.20: Knowledge that perceives the one imperishable reality in all beings, and sees all beings as non-different from it, is sattvic (pure).
18.21: Knowledge that sees diverse forms of life and is divided into different kinds, perceives differences in beings, and is rajasic (passionate).
18.22: Knowledge that is deluded by the illusion of diversity, sees only one part of the truth, and is tamasic (ignorant).
18.23: Action performed without attachment, without desire for results, and in accordance with one's duties is sattvic (pure).
18.24: Action performed with desire for results and egoistic attachment is rajasic (passionate).
18.25: Action performed under the influence of delusion, with no regard for the consequences or consequences, and with negligence is tamasic (ignorant).
18.26: A person who is free from attachment and ego, and acts with determination and enthusiasm, is called sattvic (pure).
18.27: A person who is desirous of the results of actions, greedy, violent, and unclean is called rajasic (passionate).
18.28: A person who is dull, foolish, deceitful, and lazy, and who procrastinates, is called tamasic (ignorant).
18.29: Listen to Me about the threefold division of the intellect and determination, as described according to the gunas (modes of nature).
18.30: Intellect that distinguishes between what is to be done and what is not to be done, what is to be feared and what is not to be feared, and what is bondage and what is liberation, is sattvic (pure).
18.31: Intellect that understands dharma (duty) and adharma (unrighteousness) in a perverted manner, and distinguishes between actions accordingly, is rajasic (passionate).
18.32: Intellect that is enveloped in ignorance, which considers dharma as adharma and vice versa, is tamasic (ignorant).
18.33: Determination by which the mind, senses, and prana (vital forces) are held steady through yoga is sattvic (pure).
18.34: Determination that is motivated by desire for results and that seeks to achieve dharma, artha (prosperity), and kama (pleasures) is rajasic (passionate).
18.35: Determination that is driven by sleep, delusion, and fear, and which is persistent in its lack of success, is tamasic (ignorant).
18.36: Now, listen to Me about the threefold happiness, which is attained through practice and which ultimately leads to the cessation of suffering.
18.37: Happiness that appears initially like poison but turns out to be like nectar at the end, is considered sattvic (pure), arising from self-realization and knowledge.
18.38: Happiness that is derived from the union of the senses with their objects, initially like nectar but ultimately like poison, is rajasic (passionate).
18.39: Happiness that is experienced due to delusion, laziness, and negligence, which arises from sleep and ignorance, is tamasic (ignorant).
18.40: There is no being on earth, in the heavens, or among the gods that is free from these three gunas (modes of nature).
18.41: The duties of the Brahmins, Kshatriyas, Vaishyas, and Shudras are divided according to their inherent qualities and characteristics.
18.42: Calmness, self-control, penance, purity, forgiveness, and knowledge are the qualities that define the Brahmin's duty.
18.43: Courage, valor, steadiness, and the ability to fight in battle and protect others are the qualities that define the Kshatriya's duty.
18.44: Agriculture, cattle-rearing, and trade are the qualities that define the Vaishya's duty.
18.45: Service and manual labor are the qualities that define the Shudra's duty.
18.46: One who is devoted to his own duty attains perfection. Listen to Me how one attains perfection by performing one's own duty.
18.47: By performing one's own duty according to one's nature, a person can achieve perfection.
18.48: One who performs his duty without attachment, surrendering all actions to Me, achieves eternal peace.
18.49: One who is not attached, is self-controlled, and has transcended desire, attains the highest state of liberation through renunciation.
18.50: Hear from Me how one who has attained this perfection, attains the supreme knowledge and the ultimate goal of life.
18.51-53: One who is engaged in self-discipline, has control over the senses, and is detached from desires, and who is always engaged in meditation, achieves liberation.
18.54: One who is self-realized and is free from all doubts, sees all beings equally and is devoted to Me, attains the highest state.
18.55: Through devotion, one comes to know Me as I am and thereby attains the highest knowledge.
18.56: One who performs all actions with devotion to Me, attains eternal bliss and the supreme state.
18.57: One who dedicates all his actions to Me, and remains devoted to Me with a mind focused on Me, attains liberation.
18.58: One who has surrendered all actions to Me, and has a mind absorbed in Me, will overcome all obstacles through My grace.
18.59: One who, driven by ego and ignorance, thinks that he is not bound by actions, will be misled by his own nature.
18.60: One who is bound by his own nature, will act according to his inclinations, even if he wishes otherwise.
18.61: The Supreme Lord dwells in the hearts of all beings, O Arjuna, and moves them according to His will.
18.62: Take refuge in the Supreme Lord with all your being, and through His grace, you will attain supreme peace and the eternal abode.
18.63: Thus, I have given you the most profound knowledge. Reflect on it and act according to your understanding.
18.64: O Arjuna, by My grace, I have revealed to you the most secret knowledge. Reflect on it and do as you wish.
18.65: Surrender to Me with all your heart, and you will attain the ultimate peace and liberation.
18.66: By abandoning all varieties of religiousness and taking refuge in Me alone, you will attain liberation and eternal peace.
18.67: This knowledge is the most secret and sacred. Meditate on it, and do as you wish.
18.68: One who will propagate this supreme secret knowledge to My devotees, will attain My divine grace and be blessed.
18.69: There is no one more dear to Me than the one who imparts this knowledge to My devotees, nor will there be anyone more dear.
18.70: He who studies this sacred dialogue of ours, with understanding, will be freed from the bondage of karma and attain liberation.
18.71: One who listens with faith and reverence, will attain knowledge and liberation, and will be liberated from the cycle of birth and death.
18.72: This is the most profound and sacred knowledge. Reflect upon it and act accordingly, O Arjuna.
18.73: Arjuna said: O Krishna, I have heard Your divine words, and my illusion is dispelled. I am now ready to act according to Your instructions.
18.74: The Blessed Lord said: O Arjuna, you have spoken the truth. Now, I will reveal to you the most secret knowledge.
18.75: I have revealed to you the supreme knowledge, which is the essence of all scriptures. Now, do as you wish.
18.76: Arjuna said: O Krishna, I am now fully enlightened. I have attained the supreme knowledge and will act according to Your instructions.
18.77: The Blessed Lord said: O Arjuna, you have now attained the highest wisdom. May you always remember and act accordingly.
18.78: Thus ends Chapter 18 of the Bhagavad Gita, known as the Yoga of Liberation by Renunciation.
